All the retraining in the world will be for nothing if there are not jobs available once people are trained.  We need another WPA style program to put everyone back to work who can work - and that includes people over 50 who have given up all hope of finding work after being laid off in 2008/2009. Many are discouraged workers who are being discriminated against because of their age. Others can only find part-time minimum wage jobs.  Whatever job training is offered should be relevant to the jobs that are currently available and be free to the unemployed.

Expanded training programs and better education will enable individuals to escape from the least desirable jobs, but if they all escape (through an abundance of jobs, which was not discussed in the article) these jobs will go unfilled or change themselves to become more desirable.

As long as there are a large number of low-paying jobs income inequality will be a problem and be too high. As more people get training and education, more of them will be overqualified for the jobs they hold. Only if these low-paying jobs are unfilled until employers give up, or they are legislated out of existence by a raise in the minimum wage, will income inequality go down.

I became curious about the prevalence of mutilation of young women in Morocco, a couple of years ago, after attending an anthropology lecture on FGM rituals among African tribes. To my great relief, I found out that the practice is not prevalent there as it is in Egypt and, I suspect, other Arabic nations. I came across an essay written by then PhD-candidate Meryem Fati (linked below). In it, she describes the history of FGM on the African continent before and after the advent of Islam.

It is going to be a long and very difficult fight to eradicate this most barbaric of practices. One way we can help in the West is by educating our children earlier and more thoroughly about the customs in cultures other than our own. We can bring greater awareness and demand from our leaders that they condition US aid upon the verifiable cessation of practices like FGM, and the acceptance of supplemental aid for education in women and gender studies to be implemented in those countries' public school systems. We need to educate those whose minds and hearts must be changed.
